title: Fix Focus Mode state loss bug on process death
description:
Users lose timer progress (elapsed time, medals, timer state) when Android kills the app process during extended backgrounding. Root cause: FocusViewModel uses mutableStateOf which doesn't survive process death. Solution: Use SavedStateHandle (already injected at line 40) to persist critical timer state across process death.

Implementation plan: /Users/richardthompson/StudioProjects/VoxPlanApp/.claude/scratchpad/2025-12-22_focus-mode-state-loss-bug.md

Files affected: FocusViewModel.kt (only file)
Estimated: 2-3 hours, ~150 lines of code
design: Use SavedStateHandle to persist timer state (currentTime, timerState, timerStarted, medals) to Bundle. Android automatically serializes SavedStateHandle during onSaveInstanceState() when Activity backgrounds. Restore state in ViewModel init if saved state exists (single check). Clear saved state on normal exit/banking. Follows Android best practices: update SavedStateHandle continuously (cheap in-memory writes), Android handles serialization timing automatically.

- [ ] Timer state (elapsed time) survives process death after 5+ min backgrounding
- [ ] Medals persist across process death
- [ ] Timer that was RUNNING auto-pauses on restoration with correct time
- [ ] Banked/exited sessions start fresh (no stale state restoration)
- [ ] No Bundle size exceptions (TransactionTooLargeException)
- [ ] All validation tests pass (see scratchpad Success Definition)

title: FocusMode: SavedStateHandle restores stale state after process death
description:
**CRITICAL P0 BUG**: When app is backgrounded and process is killed, timer restoration shows state from BEFORE backgrounding. Timer 'goes backwards in time' - user sees old values, not current progress.

**Evidence:**
- User starts timer, runs for 2 minutes (shows 2:00)
- User backgrounds app (home button)
- Timer continues running in background, reaches 3 minutes
- Process killed
- App reopened: Timer shows 2:00 (WRONG - went backwards!)

**Root Cause:**
Current implementation has THREE fatal flaws:
1. Uses System.currentTimeMillis() instead of SystemClock.elapsedRealtime() (can jump backwards when user changes system time)
2. Tries to save currentTime (constantly changing value) instead of start timestamp (constant)
3. SavedStateHandle writes AFTER Activity.onStop() don't persist to Bundle
4. Auto-pauses on restoration instead of auto-continuing (user wants seamless timer)

**Current Implementation Issues (Lines 103-385):**
- Line 237: System.currentTimeMillis() ❌ (not monotonic)
- Line 157: Saves currentTime (changes every second) ❌
- Line 362-365: Periodic saves every 5 seconds (don't persist after onStop) ❌
- Line 147-149: Auto-pauses on restoration ❌

**Desired Behavior:**
Timer continues seamlessly across process death. On restore:
- Timer shows correct elapsed time (3:00 in example)
- Medals awarded retroactively for time during process death
- Timer keeps ticking as though nothing happened
- User sees no interruption

**Files Involved:**
- app/src/main/java/com/voxplanapp/ui/focusmode/FocusViewModel.kt (primary changes)
- Detailed plan: scratchpad/2025-12-22-140400_fix-savedstatehandle-stale-state/plan.md

**Impact:**
Users lose focus session progress on process death. Timer resets to old values, medals vanish. Breaks core time tracking and gamification features.
design:
**CALCULATION-BASED APPROACH** using Android best practices:

**Key Components:**

1. **SystemClock.elapsedRealtime()** (not System.currentTimeMillis())
   - Monotonic clock (never goes backwards)
   - Immune to system time changes
   - Official Android recommendation for elapsed time measurement

2. **Save Start Timestamp** (not elapsed time)
   - Constant value written ONCE when timer starts
   - Saved BEFORE any backgrounding occurs
   - Doesn't need periodic updates

3. **Calculate Elapsed Time** on restoration
   - elapsed = SystemClock.elapsedRealtime() - startTimestamp
   - Includes time during process death
   - Always accurate

4. **Retroactive Medal Calculation**
   - completeRevolutions = elapsed / clockFaceMins
   - Award medals for each complete revolution
   - remainder = elapsed % clockFaceMins (current progress)

5. **Auto-Restart Timer** (seamless continuation)
   - Timer state stays RUNNING
   - Coroutine restarts with correct elapsed time
   - No manual resume needed

**Implementation Steps (11 total):**
1. Import SystemClock
2. Add KEY_START_TIMESTAMP constant
3. Replace System.currentTimeMillis() with SystemClock.elapsedRealtime()
4. Update timer job to read timestamp from SavedStateHandle
5. Remove periodic saves (not needed - timestamp is constant)
6. Modify restoreSavedState() with medal calculation logic
7. Update saveCurrentState() (medals/settings only)
8. Update pauseTimer() to save paused elapsed time
9. Update clearSavedState() to include start timestamp
10. Create unit tests
11. Create instrumented tests

**Why This Works:**
- Start timestamp saved BEFORE backgrounding ✓
- Timestamp is constant (no periodic writes needed) ✓
- Calculation reconstructs elapsed time accurately ✓
- Medals awarded retroactively ✓
- Timer appears to never stop ✓

**Reference:** scratchpad/2025-12-22-140400_fix-savedstatehandle-stale-state/plan.md (complete detailed implementation guide)
acceptance_criteria:
**Functional Success:**
- [ ] Timer uses SystemClock.elapsedRealtime() (not System.currentTimeMillis())

**Technical Success:**

**Test Scenarios:**
- [ ] Start timer for 2 mins → background → kill process → reopen → shows 2:00 (RUNNING)
- [ ] Start timer for 95 mins → kill process → reopen → shows 3 medals + 5 mins progress
- [ ] Pause timer → kill process → reopen → stays paused with correct time

**Validation:**

title: Material 3 Dark Mode: Sanity-check implementation plan before task breakdown
description:
**PLANNING COMPLETED - AWAITING SANITY CHECK**

The Material 3 dark mode implementation has been fully planned and documented. Before breaking this down into implementation tasks in beads, the plan needs technical review and sanity-checking.

**Current State:**
- VoxPlanApp has Material 3 theme infrastructure (Theme.kt) but it's completely unused
- All screens use hardcoded colors (26 constants + 42+ inline hex values)
- No dark mode support despite user demand
- Accessibility issues (no WCAG contrast guarantees)

**Planning Complete:**
- Comprehensive implementation plan created
- Color analysis completed
- Pattern analysis of existing codebase (3 anti-patterns identified)
- Android best practices research completed
- Migration strategy defined

**Plan Location:**
`scratchpad/2025-12-23-000113_material3-dark-mode/`
- plan.md (main overview, 100 lines)
- implementation-plan-v2.md (detailed steps, 39KB)
- color-analysis.md (color system analysis, 21KB)

**Proposed Approach:**
1. Migrate from hardcoded colors to Material 3 semantic color roles
2. Implement light and dark color schemes
3. Support system dark mode detection (isSystemInDarkTheme)
4. Preserve branding with extended colors (power bars, medals)
5. Files affected: 11+ screens, Theme.kt, Colors.kt

**Next Steps:**
1. Technical review of the implementation plan
2. Sanity-check proposed migration strategy
3. Validate color scheme accessibility (WCAG compliance)
4. Approve or adjust approach
5. Create detailed beads tasks for implementation

**Blocker:**
Cannot proceed with implementation until plan is reviewed and approved.
design:
The scratchpad contains three comprehensive documents:

1. **plan.md** - Strategic overview
   - Pattern analysis (3 anti-patterns in codebase)
   - Recommended Material 3 approach
   - External documentation references
   - Integration impact analysis

2. **implementation-plan-v2.md** - Tactical implementation
   - Step-by-step migration guide
   - Before/after code examples
   - Dependency ordering
   - Test strategy

3. **color-analysis.md** - Color system design
   - Material 3 color role mapping
   - Accessibility analysis
   - Extended color definitions (branding)

**Review Focus Areas:**
- Is the Material 3 migration approach sound?
- Are the proposed color schemes accessible?
- Is the migration strategy realistic (11+ files)?
- Should we do incremental rollout or full migration?
- Are extended colors correctly implemented?
- Do we keep dynamic colors (Android 12+ wallpaper-based)?

**Decision Points:**
1. Full migration vs incremental (screen by screen)?
2. Dynamic color support (true/false)?
3. Extended color approach for branding?
4. Timeline and resource allocation?
